You get tired of the richness after a couple of bites and it was just not something I would order again.  Japanese Cheesecake with guava sorbet, honeydew, champagne granita (i think it was $9-10) Very light and fluffy the mixture of the guava sorbet, honeydew and cheesecake was a perfect combination. I think compared to the PB&J this was my kind of dessert.  Mango Tango Bellini sparkling wine, mango syrup, mango-tangerine sorbet...8  Strawberry Kiss sparkling wine, ginger ale, frozen strawberry...8  None of the drinks impressed me, maybe it was because I was already tipsy from happy hour at another place or I felt that I can make something similar at home. Overall, this place was ok.  Tons of board games, but the place inside is really dark so it would be a little difficult to play.   PARKING SUCKS!

jisQEtwfrOKBmssWoiXljg.review_text: Delicious, mouth watering desserts. Good pairing with their selection of wines. Cozy, very welcoming environment for a group of friends - like a girls not out. Cute place and cute owner :)

_UwMPlKVRPtdLtW1a5Fvbw.review_text: Candybar is a little gem tucked away in Nopa Valley, but I'm not too sure what the hype is all about.   I consider this place a fancy Starbucks. Great to come on a date, or with a group of pals to chat or play board games with (which they have). I love champagne and their jasmine champagne tasted like a boozin' flowery soda pop. Loved it.  Onto the candy part of this bar. I really didn't care for their desserts, nor did any of my other pals. It came on this huge platter (you know, like the kind you would use at Harrah's Buffet in Reno.) On top of that, the dessert just looked somewhat sloppy. I wanted to stay positive and think that it was going to taste better since it looked not good. Nope, wrong again. Just like that brightly colored butterfly the sparrow had it's eye on. It goes and swoops.. ack.. the damn thing is poison. The sparrow dies.  Back to the Candybar. To sum things up, this place is like the Gilroy Garlic Festival. Great to check out once, but with no desire to go back.

-PoCbyNa4xc4yvReuj5pqw.review_text: Krispy Kreme bread pudding?!  Five stars just for that.  I'm usually tipsy by the time I get here so I might be biased saying everything is fabulous.

Te18TxvzfLomGE56N7s3Dw.review_text: There aren't too many dessert places in SF, at least not that I know of where you can sit down in a nice comfortable setting.  You can always go to restaurants or XYZ bar and have a dessert but it isn't the same.  Having said that we've been wanting to come to CandyBar for a long time.  Every time we drove over we could not find parking.  As all the other reviews say, parking is a bit**.  We were lucky last night and got a spot after circling just once.  Onto the food.  The gf got the red velvet cake with mint ice cream.  I'm not a fan of red velvet cake but it was beautifully made with coconut covering the outside and luscious red inside.  The mint ice cream...refreshing.  It was more of a in between ice cream and sorbet where it was light yet creamy.  The red velvet was a bit on the sweet and creamy side but when eaten with the mint ice cream, it balances eachother well perfectly.  I had the french macaron with vanilla bean ice cream (sandwiched in between).  I couldn't taste much blueberry flavor for the macaron except for the blueberries they put inside.  Haivng said that I've been a fan of ice cream and macaron put together.  The two other places that have this combination, Gary Danko and also Chocolux (I think that is the right name) in Hong Kong.  Anyway you can't go wrong with macaron and ice cream.    We also ordered delicious jasmine cocktail was one of the best cocktails I've had in a long time.  I'll definitely go back even if they don't change their menus as I can have the macaron and ice cream and the jasmine cocktail every time.  They did tell me they change their menu every so often.

UNGQWhMyJqMqDQNk1ffbNg.review_text: If you are looking for some gooey, rich, decadent dessert, don't come here.  I already had lowered expectations based on the prior Yelp reviews.  And, sadly, I still was disappointed.  We had the chocolate pave with foam, raspberries with shortbread, and the brioche everyone's been raving about.    The brioche was nothing to write home about.  Yes, it was good compared to the other options, but that's because the other desserts were not that great.  The chocolate was the least tasty.  Something seemed off.  The desserts are very light (like Asian-style desserts) and bland.  It is too bad, because the staff was very attentive and nice.  I want to like this place more, but I can't until they improve the taste of the treats.

DpbQMqF6OVdxURD-jPiwnA.review_text: Very cute little place. It was hard to find but truly is a hidden gem. The jasmine champaign I think was what I had is average, but their desserts re delish.

rghHiBkf79wRQN5e5E7e9g.review_text: the ambience of this place is great...I dropped by for the grand opening and was not dissapointed.  The wine selection is excellent.  A great place to go if your with a bunch of friends or if your a wine junkie...

QsWZ9Y1Ffh42w_JQe6ITTg.review_text: I just love this place for what it is.  I looks like an art gallery to me, a little minimalist, but still cozy enough to sit with friends.  The service is attentive and friendly, but not over-bearing, and there is a cute selection of board games and books, should you find yourself here with someone who bores you.  ;)  Here's what our group had: Started with a couple of savories, just in case (okay, really because we felt guilty about having ALL dessert!) - the sweet and spicy toasted almonds were a nice crunchy start.  The carrot soup was DIVINE - I could have eaten a whole gallon of it!  The texture was just pure velvet, and the flavor was perfect.  The pork terrine was also very good (plus, I love anything that comes with cornichons!).  Now, on to dessert, folks!  Two of us had the dessert tasting menu paired with wines, while one opted for the cheese plate.  I was lucky enough to sample everything (I'm just that persuasive!)  The cheese plate was very good - 4 different cheeses, along with some medjool date paste and walnut bread.  Starter - strawberry, mint, and  lemon frappe.  I've loved frappes since I had them at Friendly's growing up on the east coast.  This was a delicious start!  Chevre cheesecake with coconut sorbet and nicoise olive caramel (paired with a vin de raisins).  While the wine didn't knock my socks off, the cheesecake was DELICIOUS!  I could eat it every night!  Carrot Cake baked Alaska with candied fennel and walnuts (paired with a Brigantino).  Not quite enough carrot cake for me to feel comfortable calling it a carrot cake, but the meringue on the baked Alaksa part is pretty damn delicious.  Likewise on the Brigantino, which could be the perfect red, effervescent dessert wine!  Warm Vanilla Cake with pickled mango and olive oil (paired with a Sauternes).  Very good cake!  The flavor is intense (which is probably why it is so small), but the accoutrements handle it well, as does the wine.  Fourme d'Ambert Panna Cotta with caramel dates and cinnamon toast (paired with a vin Santo).  Let me be honest.  This stole the show.  I adore blue, stinky cheese, and this is probably the most unique dessert I've ever tasted.  Intense sweet from the dates, with creamy tartness from the blue cheese was perfection.  Add some cinnamon toast in there, and it was amazing.  Just awesome.  I don't remember the wine much, because I was swooning over this dish.  To finish:  Warm malted milk with peanut butter cookies.  It doesn't get any more comforting than this, folks.  The malted milk is absolutely delicious (you'd wish you got a whole huge mug of it to take to bed with you!), and the cookies a sweet touch.   As if all this weren't enough, we were brought out a Tin Roof Sundae on the house.  We were all totally full, blood sugar out of control, but somehow managed to devour it.  The intense chocolate sweetness with the salty peanuts and cool vanilla ice cream was a wonderful end to our "meal" (yes, our meal of DESSERT!).  I know this was a long review, but I really loved this place.  I will be back again as soon as I'm in SF again!

C7pEB1z7QpRtL1sxqeOTww.review_text: Meh. After a rad Japanese dinner and film at the Kabuki, I was craving dessert and my homie wanted a drink. We headed over to this spot despire her warnings that it was not all that. Let me say I don't think it's bad in and of itself, but we were definitely not feeling it. It was a very squealy 20something crowd (complete with bachelorette party in tiaras and sashes) and heavily female (and Asian, for some reason....go figure), which I guess makes sense since girls dig cake. Very slick and 'new San Francisco' for me, but the artwork was GREAT - nice job, guys. The dessert selection was tough, as I'm a purist and don't want any lavender-infused or honey-kissed melon bullshit polluting my chocolate (almost EVERY dessert had fruit in some form, and I like my fruit raw and fresh, not sullying my creamy chocolate indulgence - I realize this makes me a freak and this opinion is TOTALLY subjective). We ordered a coffee (I asked the adorable server if it was fresh and he assured it me that was and he wasn't lying, and this was 11pm, so big ups to the Candy Bar for that), a port (she said it was just OK) and the chocolate chip cookie thing and some apple pie-ish thing, both of which were OK.....but $10 for two ordinary cookies and a cocoa (it wasn't clear to either us from the menu that a hot cocoa was part of this dish) is a bit over the top for me. If you were born in the late 80s or - let me just catch my breath here - early 90s, this might be your speed, but for us jaded Gen X OG's, it wasn't what the doctor ordered.

fTG5GrYEjTX2MrNrfboh0Q.review_text: Seriously, good name for a dessert place :)  Can't blame it, everything is right and gorgeous.   All cocktails, especially sangrias, desserts are freaking delicious and beautifully served, but the main thing that got my attention - ice-cream sandwich..  Cozy, warm atmosphere - best place to bring your date to :)

VdUjcjZeSF7sH8Z-OZfIag.review_text: Came here for birthday dessert on a Saturday night - spent over 20 minutes looking for parking.  Once we were inside there were only a few people there.  Some were playing games while others were chatting quietly to themselves.  The place definitely has a chill and relaxing ambiance to it - just what I typically look for but seemed a little strange that the place was so empty.   We ordered the Fudgesicle and one other dessert (pictures posted) and it seems that the sweets menu rotates every so often as it's no longer on the current menu (the current desserts of chocolate mousse and red velvet cake sound much more appealing!).  We had a strawberry italian soda and a strawberry kiss to drink. We were underwhelmed by everything other than the presentation of the desserts which was lovely.  Definitely willing to give this place another shot if we're ever in the area!

BKoViiKKyUo9y-1M8IndXw.review_text: I love the Candy Bar!  It always cheers me up even after driving around for 20 minutes to find a parking spot.  If I didn't live so far in the Excelsior, I'd totally ride my bike here.  The Chocolate Espresso Pudding with maple bacon pecan crunch is worth the trek.  I also recommend the Peanut Butter Jelly Time!  It's a sophisticated take on my childhood favorite.  They have a smorgasbord of board games to choose from, so it's fun to go there with friends and pig out;-)

0n4jYoztlDLVWSsycvprGA.review_text: Exceptional desserts, which are creative and delicious. Nice bar and coffee selection complements the desserts. Attractive, comfortable, and relaxed. Great place for a date or to catch up with a friend.

2r440W55zPn5nLbeMgDK3A.review_text: Came here on a first day and it was so cute at 11pm on a Saturday night. They were able to seat us after 15 minutes which was quite nice. Looking around there were alot of couples and groups here.   The cutest part of this was that everyone was able to play board games at their tables which is a very interesting concept that I've never seen at a dessert/wine shop.   I ordered the Strawberry kiss as my drink and we also ordered a dessert to share but I can't remember what it was called! I just remember it being really yummy and had fresh strawberries and ice cream around it.   I recently purchased a groupon here and will be returning soon. Their happy hour prices are to good to be true and the groupon deal allows you to use it during hh time too I think :)

7_ZDTjIUmNqI7xvEeysOmw.review_text: This place is fun, yummy, and chill!  Friends were coming into the city and we wanted to find a place that had drinks and lounge areas where you can chat at a normal volume.  Most places we could think of were more club-like and we would lose our voices by the end of the night just trying to talk to each other.  Candybar is perfect for a place you want to hang out with your friends over dessert and drinks.  You can even bring your own dinner if you want!  Tan helped me throughout the night and with my reservations.  He was very responsive the entire time we were there.  The sangrias are yummy, I also tried the chocolate cremeux cake and the cheesecake. The chocolate cake was so delicious, and with the black currant sauce, and thyme ice cream it was even more divine!  I would give it five stars although our waiter didn't look like he was having a good day and it took a really long time for our drinks to come out.

At_IyfTydvfq_HmA4OgpEQ.review_text: Can you say Dessert Heaven? Love, Love, Love This Place!   Came here with my boyfriend for our 2 years and 2 months. He bought a Groupon Deal a while back (2 drinks and 2 dessert entree) and wanted to use it up before it expired. It was pretty nice place for a date I tell you. Nice way to make the night perfect. We sat down by the window side and tried to figure out what dessert dish we should try and unfortunately from the drinks, their mostly alcoholic drinks to choose from. i asked which drinks they can put non-alcohol - cause I'm expecting. They said Strawberry Kiss or the Mango Tango Bellini which I got the Strawberry Kiss. My boyfriend got the Lychee one (I uploaded a picture of how it looks like). For dessert there was so much to choose from and seems so tempted to taste all of it. But I got the Honey - Almond Panna Cotta (berrys, vanilla pudding sliced up, scoop of chocolate ice cream, and caramel powder - took a picture). My boyfriend got the Strawberry Limeade (strawberry mouse layered with vanilla cake and caramel cream on top of strawberries - took a picture). Taste good huh? IT WAS!   It made the night perfect. Maybe when we are around, and wanting dessert, we'll come back. :)    PS. 6-8pm is Happy Hour! Check it out.

lrp5aQP31ar3JDlbwccfHQ.review_text: I came here on a Friday night and it was busy.  It didn't take long to get a table.  My friend and I had the Strawberry Limeade and Green Tea Bread Pudding.  They were both soooo good!  The only thing I didn't like was the Jasmine Sparkle (cocktail).  That drink was just too sweet especially when having it with dessert.  Otherwise, I would love to come back here!!!

ypi79ZvMEwlW7aNcrb418g.review_text: I love coming to Candybar! Not only does this place sell delicious desserts, but drinks & boardgames? Totally sold.  Candybar has a nice selection of both desserts and cocktails, though not all are always available. Most of their choices are pretty good, but I definitely have a clear favourite:  Peanut Butter Jelly Time!!!   I seriously have the worst memory, but returning to Candybar 5 months later, all I could think about was how amazing that peanut butter dessert was. It's a perfect melange of flavours: not too sweet, and it's peanut butter & chocolate (such a good combo!).   Come early (6-8p), and order a happy hour cocktail for $4!

LpkGQpKFFICLfdIBxB2nAA.review_text: This place is good but I guess I just expected to walk into a Willy Wonka wonderland. But it was basically just a little bar/cafe with some art on the walls. Kind of disappointing.  The tiramisu was ok but nothing spectacular. Good tiramisu is really hard to find but still..it's a dessert bar, so they should be awesome. They are huge, however. The drinks are ok - they serve beer, wine and some variations of sparkling wine with fruity juices. Nothing special. The service was also nothing special.  Other than that...the bathroom is cute?  If the place had a full bar and better tiramisu, it would for sure be 5 stars for sure.

jkr3YVCEoRNKkxinUZpW6A.review_text: We celebrated my friend's birthday at Candybar.  Saturday night and the place was incredibly packed, pretty amazing for having been open only one week.    There was a pretty large list of dessert wines, some choices for sparkling/champagne, and a few reds/whites. The bartender was helpful in finding me a nice chardonnay and the bday girl loved her riesling, though it came in a very tiny flute ($11).   On to the sweets:  The baked Alaska was unavailable, as was their only mixed wine cocktail.   We were not offered a tasting menu.  Chevre cheesecake ($8)- turned into a puddle after sitting at our table for a mere five minutes.  We spooned it up like a soup, which I assume was not the chef's intention.  Warm vanilla cake ($8)- really enjoyed this, especially the contrast of the pickled mangos with the cake.  Chocolate brioche ($8)- tasted like a molten chocolate cake, easily our favorite of the night.  Inventive to pair with a balsamic ice cream.  Cheese plate ($11)- three types cheeses, a bit of bread, and fig paste. Two of the cheeses were very similar, though enjoyable.  Small annoyances: Given the food options, we'd assumed Candybar to be more lounge than bar-like, and yet there really isn't much seating or tables.  How do you eat dessert standing up?  The lounge area had small coffee tables at an awkward height, difficult for eating and couldn't even fit all of our dishes.    Wines by the bottle were quite overpriced- a few in the $250- $300 range, but many more were $70+.       The place is brand new and I hope their issues will be worked out soon enough.    The desserts are actually quite interesting and delicious, definitely making Candybar worth a visit.

aSB77ckbtSVb43As_H8MjQ.review_text: This place is one of the best in the cities for drinks and dessert. I go here all the time with my g/f. The owner is great a really nice and guy and the service is great as well. The only thing that is not great is the parking.. But if you drive around the block about 3-4 times you will find a spot. But I really recommend this place if you have not been here yet. A great place to go for a nice quit night out on the town!

u3QEuCVt1vwCk1Ewv7vlhw.review_text: Love it!  We go often  A little pricey but worth it

hYrd3Ozj5WLXn3yIi3BZgg.review_text: This place never seems to disappoint. It's real swanky and hipster, perfect to my liking. The art on the walls, the music, the board games--it fits. I've tried almost all the desserts here. My favorite is the flourless chocolate cake. It's crack chocolate. There are pieces of citrus-y lime in the slab of white chocolate. Crackworthy.  Parking on the other hand, good luck.. But I've found parking every single time I've driven here... and that's saying something.  Bring your baby mamas here--you won't regret it.

aKAGlmoKsgnQ8Avh86-SOg.review_text: Yum, yum, and more yum. I came here after dinner at Bar Crudo, and it was the perfect thing to follow our not-too-filling dinner. The desserts here are light and not overbearing, and don't hit you like a ton of bricks! They're artfully done, and there's board games to boot! I dig this place a lot, and would come back the next time I'm in the neighborhood.   The boy ordered the chocolate fudgesicle. I have to admit, I was a bit concerned by the idea of caramelized corn nuts, but they were pretty good. I'm also a huge fan of vanilla ice cream, and that was good here. But I didn't pay too much attention to what the boy ordered, because my order was pretty amazing. I got the nacho sundae, which sounds disgusting, until you actually see it in front of you. The "cheddar cheese" is mango slices, there's candied jalapeno, and the "sour cream" is horchata ice cream. And the nachos themselves were like sweetened crackers with bits of sugar on them. I was astounded. It looked like nachos (served in the red basket and everything) but everything was sweet! It was delicious. I also had the Strawberry kiss, which was pretty much what I wanted after having a sample of dessert wine at Bar Crudo. It was delicious and sweet and reminded me of having Fragolino in Italy, something I've wanted to have again since, but haven't been able to find.  They also have Candyland (which I've never played, and tried to this time and failed because there were no instructions) and Connect Four, which kept us busy until our orders came. We came on a Thursday and it wasn't crowded at all. I love the idea of this place, and I think it's executed pretty well. I just wish it were a little closer to where I live!

6gd8upNZ9YEmIvwzQsVvOw.review_text: I came here with my girlfriends on a Friday night, for an all girl outing. I must say it was nice. Their deserts are beautiful and yummy. The drinks are delicious. The place is on the smaller side and it is very cozy. They have all kinds of kids' board games which of course we played. And I must say I was kind of impressed by the bathroom. All in all it was a nice experience. The downside I made a reservation for nine we didn't get seated until almost ten... the upside free bubbly while we waited :)

7VbDRTjZuh8WFcilyb7_HA.review_text: My husband found Candybar and brought me here to celebrate the 8th anniversary of our first date. We happened to come in for the last 30 minutes of happy hour so we were able to try the Jasmine Sparkle and the Strawberry Kiss on the cheap! The flavors of both drinks were subtle (maybe a little too subtle on the Jasmine but perfect in the Strawberry) and the bubbles made the drinks fun!  For dessert, we tried the sampler for two: we got to choose 4 desserts from the menu to share. We had the Strauss Yogurt Cake, Apple a la Mode, Lemon Tart, and the Lavender Honey Creme Fraiche Semi Freddo. The standouts were the Lemon Tart and the Yogurt Cake. The flavors were balanced delicately and perfectly. I thought the flavors of the Semi Freddo dish were a bit muted and the Apple a la Mode was way too sweet for my palate. (Fair warning: my palate is geared more toward rich and creamy, not sugar-sweet.) Overall, I was terribly impressed with the desserts and I cannot wait to go back and try some more!  We grabbed a game of Battleship and ordered another cocktail: the Passion Fruit Delight. I was worried the passion fruit syrup would be too sweet but to my happy surprise it was perfect! (Passion fruit is my favorite!) We had a lot of fun playing boardgames though the dim lighting made it difficult to see at times. I wish it was just a tad brighter in the room. I love, love, LOVE the asian-inspired art on the walls and the open, contemporary decor. I look forward to coming back with my hubby, playing games, and sipping more cocktails. One word of warning, and maybe this is to be expected, many of the games were missing pieces or instructions so once we landed on a complete game, we were wary of switching to another. Of course, we just started making up our own rules to the games and that was fun too!  Candybar is fun, romantic, and would be great for a date or a night out with the girls. Check it out!

RIZe3gi79Ko28xgG3dyzNQ.review_text: I haven't written a review on @CandybarSF yet??  Someone slap the dessert fork out of my hand until I finish typing!  Favorite dessert: Ice Cream Sandwich made with a huge French macaron - I've ordered it twice already (see pics of blueberry one back in April and green tea one in June) and will keep ordering this each time I visit.  Note: I'm very delighted that Chef Catherine Li has decided to launch her new Oui Oui Macaron line.  I am already a follower!  Runner-up: Strawberry Limeade - a sweet and tart parfait in a cute jar!  Go-to cocktail: 50/50 - soju, orange soda, vanilla = orange creamsicle winner!  Please excuse all the exclamation points...this place has captured my sweet tooth.  The only downside is the lack of parking that goes hand-in-hand with the prime location, but I can't dock a full star for that.  ~ Meet me at the Candybar ~

wVpwTZ0ynSgHWn_tgzx2vg.review_text: I imagine this is how King Kandy's palace would look if it was foreclosed and repo'ed by Silicon Valley.  Candyland for the yuppies, if you will.  I think that serious businessmen and big-kids alike will enjoy Candybar's treasure trove of treats.  The venue is small, intimate and tres chic.   I sampled a few rounds of goodies:  Brioche Beignets with Spearmint Sugar, Cornmeal cake with sticky carrot and cheese crema, and the ice cream and sorbet selection (Mint chocolate chip, Ginger and Dolce de leche).  The beignets are tiny, but authentic (minus the New Orleans' style powder sugar) and the carrot cornmeal cake was out of this world.  The ice cream arrived in mini mason jars and supplied about 2 spoonfulls each between three people.  I hear they completely overhaul the menu every month and I can't wait to sample some sugarplum, gingerbread holiday goodness in December.  Under normal circumstances I would rate this place a solid three stars (mainly since I didn't have any wine and cannot comment on the pairings), but the service was outstanding.  What a nice group of people.   Two different chefs came out to greet us and the waiter chatted us up.  The warm and welcoming atmosphere will secure a second visit from me.   In addition, I think Candybar would be an awesome post-dinner date stop in the neighborhood.  You know what they say, "Candy is dandy, but liquor is quicker!"

KcEfVfc5nTPBDonYjJ3wOw.review_text: MM! This place is great! Came here last night, expecting it to be packed but it wasn't. It has a very trendy and intimate environment but it does get noisy. Has a shelf for board games! INTENSE.  I got the flourless chocolate cake with strawberry sherbert, very good.  Service was alright... waitress seemed kind of bleh... after taking our order.

TMLVzNYs-zwwREudyvI08A.review_text: Yet another place near my home that I can get kicked out of.  At least here I have a shot at scoring some tasty port and/or desert before aforementioned forced removal.  Nice addition to the neighborhood.

lJOIRINR22HvbGI_ZTsOPg.review_text: My roommate, friend, and I were looking for a game night / something mellow, as she was getting over the flu.  And I wanted somewhere I could get a drink.  Per usual, we turned to Yelp for a neighborhood recommendation, and found this lovely place.  So happy we did.  The inside is great.  Extremely intimate, warm, and swanky with its deep red walls, and suggestive art pieces.   Everyone seems to mention the parking issue.  Who drives in this city, anyway?  Especially on a weekend night!   Anyway, we arrived at around 9:15 on a rainy Saturday night, and were told it would be about a 15 - 30 minute wait.  So, we loitered inside until our names were called, promptly 15 minutes later, and were taken to a small table.  The table - most of the tables - are a bit small for the featured board games (which they have plenty of - good ones, too) - they might be better suited for cards or something.  There were about four larger tables / booth areas near the entrance - perfect for games - which may require a reservation.  I can't say the service was warm and friendly.  Our guy, as well as the host were a little aloof and disinterested, but oh well.   Roommate ordered the lavender honey creme fraiche semi freddo, which I took a bite of - delicious.  Her friend ordered the chocolate financier cake, which was good, but I didn't find to be spectacular.  She didn't love it either.  And me, having eaten 3/4 of a pint of Ben and Jerry's earlier that day (no, I'm not depressed, I was just craving it, okay?!), i opted to just get the jasmine sparkle: champagne, jasmine, and lemon.  It sounds tantalizing, doesn't it?  Well, it wasn't.  It just tasted like sweet champagne; I didn't taste even a hint of jasmine or lemon.  Overall, a great place that I highly recommend.  Perhaps their other cocktails are a bit better, or maybe you should just go for something simple, like a glass of red wine with dessert.

xs7ZS0w8A0jvi4a-xL1vBA.review_text: I've been going here since the first week they opened and I really enjoyed the ambiance, delicious desserts, and cocktail drinks to pair. It was a great place for a date or with large groups. I've taken probably 15+ people there to try it out over the years. It's been a year since I've been back, and I took my girlfriend who has never been. We were ready to order, but were ignored for a good 20 minutes as the staff walked back and forth seeing that we were ready but not acknowledging us. I get it, it was busy and I have worked in the service industry so I understand, but 20 minutes is excessive especially when you are looking at us and just waiting around. The desserts have definitely gone down in quality though. We got the sampler ( you get to choose 4 to try) and here's the breakdown:  Our macaroons came out stale for the ice cream sandwiches, ice cream was melted, apple pie and semifredo were okay (nothing amazing from what I remember the first time I had it). The only thing positive was the torte: it was delicious.   It was after we were finished and decided to play games that we were given the bill and the staff basically stalked our table to hurry us along. We were then asked to leave because people were waiting ( probably 15 minutes after I had paid). I have never had that happened to us before at Candybar.   Maybe we had to keep buying more stuff in order to stay or they changed their policy where if you pay you have to leave. I understand it is a business, but next time, tell us if you just want to make money. It saddened me because I have never had this happened at Candybar and I don't think I will be coming back. I don't want to support local businesses that will do that to their patrons.

c4u44Vmr2SnnypS_pRJJqg.review_text: Pricey for an average execution of dessert and drinks.

Da_ZO8lKwIacljqKUJbAlw.review_text: looking for a chill place to hang out in the city while satisfying your sweet tooth and need to play board games?  well, candybar is your place then!  super yummy (and beautiful) desserts, tasty bubbly cocktails (and a happy hour 'til 8pm), and a multitude of board games (like apples to apples!) make this a great spot for friends or significant others alike!

MF-WgJHyaKF3avhbQ5Uaqw.review_text: How can you go wrong with dessert and alcohol... AND board games? Everything about this place is awesome.. Expect Parking... Now that, I'm not a fan of.

L710jxONO3hfetWZB1tnqQ.review_text: Great place to take a date post-dinner, or a fun girls night get together that doesn't involve shoving alcohol down your throat and proceeding to the dance floor to embarrass yourselves.   Lots of fruity sweet desserts and board games. Parking is kind of a pain, but the desserts are well worth it!

qstOF_b3pvyVPyq4Qsyw-A.review_text: this place is pretty cool. came here with two friends on a saturday night and surprisingly it wasnt as crowded as you would think. yes we had to wait but there wasnt a huge que or anything like that. i got myself the cheesecake and i've had better cheesecake. the other things that came with it though were quite tasty which was this mousse and pear w/ alcohol puree thingy. i also had myself a mexican coke which doesnt quite compliment dessert but i couldnt resist. love that they have board games to play so you can get some serious drinking going on or just enjoy dessert with friends. make sure your entire party is there or they wont seat you. even if one is missing they wont seat you. thats kind of lame.  warning, parking is like damn near impossible in nopa/western addition area. be ready to either walk far or loop around the area for hella long.

fgkJ6KUlrmbKyLDQervxsw.review_text: I am quite familiar with dessert lounges having been a patron of Extraordinary Desserts in San Diego for many years now, but I realized I've never come across a non-Asian dessert place in San Francisco. The idea of a dessert lounge removes it as the last course of a meal and changes it into a piece of art as much as it is the centerpiece of your dining experience. Candybar (which I later realized was also a play on words), has alcohol, sweets, art, and even boardgames. But, be prepared to wait, because this place can get busy - we waited half an hour. One thing I didn't like about this place was the informal living room style seating arrangements. The coffee table and the Ottoman benches were way too low, which led to stiff necks and sore backs. But, let's discuss the desserts.  I ordered the Japanese cheesecake and tried two other desserts. I was curious to find out how it was different from your typical New York cheesecake and found the Japanese version to be a lot lighter and airy. I can only describe it as a cheesecake-flavored angel cake. The graham cracker crumbs were a nice contrasting touch. I could appreciate the champagne granita technique, but didn't think it went together with the cheesecake. The guava sorbet was also really good and one of the smoothest (both in texture and presentation) sorbets I've had. I also tried the strawberry limeade, which essentially tasted like a strawberry shortcake in a jar. I also had a bite of the green tea macaron, which was part of the ice cream sandwich. That is probably the biggest macaron I've ever seen, which was cool to see as part of an ice cream sandwich. The mango tango bellini was also very refreshing to wash down the desserts.  I loved the presentation on all the desserts and I thought the portion sizes were also good. This place is a great after dinner date place to go to, but they have to raise the comfort level of the seating and tables for their taller patrons.

G2FVUXuLEGc2fDTWFaQplw.review_text: You don't go to Candybar with an appetite for a bbq'd wild boar and beer purchased from Sam's Club (Wasilla's finest)...you go to Candybar to taste the fine wine, chocolate baked in truffle oil while you laugh at the people who cling to their religions and bask at your privileged life and status.  A desert/wine bar/lounge, Candybar is a creative concept in the restaurant industry that seems to be one of the many popping up in trendy SF. The architecture is sleek, minimalist, modern. It felt cool to be in a cool atmosphere. It's just too bad that I did have an appetite for bbq CHICKEN but can do without the beer. My pal and I had a desert sampler tray which they had brought out each desert one by one long enough for us to analyze the last batch of sweets. The service was great...the waiter and bartender were attentive and informative on the items we had ordered (i.e. The orange and regular sangrias were yum) my stomach growled the rest of the night but a lounge I would go back to and hang out...

IucvvxdQXXhjQ4z6Or6Nrw.review_text: Good option to satisfy your sweet cravings. The chocolate smore was like a tart that came with a chocolate base, caramel and marshmallow and was very good. The strawberry macaron which was huge was really good too.  I did feel bad for around 30 minutes for ODing on sugar. It was worth it though.

bGcD-uIPk0v5Fei6DS5G2g.review_text: I love this place!! I went here after my valentine dinner with the bf at Crustacean. It was a sunday night, and we didn't know what else to do after dinner. A couple friends of mine recommended this place since it's pretty popular on yelp. This place is really cute! We don't have anything like this in San Jose, but someone should def open one here. The decor is really nice and I love the ambiance. It's very relaxing and intimate. I think I would have a great time regardless with the bf or the girls. I really want to take the girls here actually lol. We ordered some tea with our dessert. We order the sampler with 4 different dessert. The bf ordered the peanut butter something.. and then the ice cream sandwich? I didnt like any of it.. I got the pie a la mode and the lavender something... I forgot the name but its the one that everyone else is talking about lol. But the pie a la mode was not bad.. and I REALLY like the lavender one. It was deliciouss. My bf didn't like it much though. His favorite was the pie a la mode. But I think I would stick to one dessert next time. Having 4 different dessert on one plate isnt such a great idea once its melted. It was sorta disgusting lol. Overall, I wasn't impressed with the dessert... but I definitely would come back bc of the great service and the ambiance. We also started playing board games... then we saw 2 other couples got up to get their own game started. =) Overall, its a great time, and Candybar is something different and enjoyable.

xwhDvpei1SrwUJjawvfgkQ.review_text: Desserts + Drinks = Genius!   This place is small, so it can get cramped and tight easily.  We opted to go with the pick four desserts for $25.    Peanut butter jelly - thick, and way too peanutty for me! Japanese cheese cake - skipped since I don't eat cheese of any kind Flourless chocolate cake - super dense, definitely not as good as other flourless chocolate cakes I've had Apple a la mode - gingerbread ice cream was good  I must admit, the desserts was a bit of a let down.  I was still craving for desserts after I got home! That says a lot! It wasn't as visually pleasing as I'd hope and definitely didn't taste that great either.  I won't be returning for the desserts again, but drinks during happy hour, maybe.  They have happy hour from 6pm - 8pm! $3 sangrias, $4 cocktails and plenty of others.  I had a shot of the lemon sorbet soju and it was tasty! Loved the line of sugar on the rim. Slurp!

T8z_UWMnE_m_Xh7DzhENtw.review_text: I really like this place. It's kind of overpriced, but the desserts and wine selection are great!   If you go in a group (more than 2 people), I don't think it's worth the price to do the dessert sampler that they have. It's better to have everyone order a la carte and then pass around & share if you want. Otherwise you end up paying like $25 a person for tiny portion sizes.

nK_aZKxrVIIgehcMgGcRRA.review_text: Cute place for a date or a night out with the girls! My girlfriends and I went around 10pm on a Saturday night and waited about 10 mins for a table. The place is pretty small, so probably during peak hours, the wait must be long.  Their menu doesn't have that much items when it comes to desserts; theres more drinks such as cocktails, dessert wine, and champagne. But that's fine with me because there's less to choose from which helps make my decision easier. Or else I would want to order all the desserts on the menu The desserts were so good. Kind of expensive around $10 each, but really good. We got the tiramisu, the ice cream sandwich which is a large macaroon but theres ice cream inside, and one other thing but I forgot the name. The ice cream sandwich was my favorite. For drinks, I tried the passion fruit cocktail which was just okay. It's tasted like a glass of moscato or prosecco. My friends got the 50/50 (yogurt soju), some mango cocktail, and the stawberry kiss cocktail. The mango and strawberry kiss ones were really good.

v3Ux6TH7YJM8neKohsAnjg.review_text: Very romantic place - it is small and cozy.  I don't recommend it if you have a big party.    A must try - Peanut Butter Jelly Time!  So good!!  They also have a good drink menu.

B-Dhfu42z8Ak4BYaS1xpsA.review_text: The desserts at Candybar are AMAZING.   Three people having a total of six desserts in one sitting (after having dinner across the street)... is that called obesity?  No, I think it's just unavoidable after you taste the unique, homemade ice creams, sauces, & dessert combinations.  Top it all off with a cappuccino or muscat, and you are in heeeaaaven!  I can't forget to add that the service is excellent. The owner himself has served us several times and gives the best suggestions of what to order.   I only wish they were open later for those late night cravings.

YoWIoYn7KUW3w8rbGqwBuw.review_text: It was okay, but not great. We had s'mores and the ice cream sundae, and found both to be kind of overbearing. For a place that specializes in dessert, I would have expected a defter hand.

tGs6oeCD2RRviyYnjfS42g.review_text: Wow! What a gem! Who doesn't love dessert, booze and board games?!?!  I was introduced to Candy Bar, some two years ago by my cousin. When we arrived the place was packed. After waiting about 30 minutes for our party of 8 to be seated we got a prime seat next to the window. The place is quaint but very comfy, they have dimmed lighting, popping music (loud), and a huge array of drinks and desserts to choose from. We ordered the Peanut Butter Jelly Time, Strawberry Limeade, Apple a la Mode, Macaroon Ice Cream Sandwich and Carrot Cake to nosh on. We also ordered several strawberry kiss cocktails, blood orange cocktails and some soju shots.   The desserts were exceptional. They were sweet and decadent and just exuded with amazing flavors. My favorite by far was the macaroon ice cream sandwich, which had blueberry ice cream smashed between two chewy macaroons.  The drinks were good, but the blood orange cocktail was a bit bitter for my taste, but again that's a personal preference. The drinks in general were great! Most of the drinks on their list seem to be made with wine or champagne, which may be a downer for those looking for a stronger drink.  Parking is very hard to find. At times we would have to drive around for 15 minutes just to find a spot 3 blocks away-- but hey it's SF that is the norm.  Fast forward ahead two years, and I still frequent this dessert spot every few months. It's seriously is a addicting treat!

wJ7HE2Is8UyFAgBIcHgqqQ.review_text: Title: Online Dating Smart Tips-1st Date Dessert  You may have been on bads dates, one that you constantly hug your watch and wait for the time to pass. It happens, and you want to call   date police.     so Grasshopper, Confuscious say   "Start with dessert on first date, if no GOOD, lossi ONLY Few Dolla"  While parking was brisk, a spoonful of panna cotta calmed the senses.  I wish I had a Smart Car.  Embedded between residential houses on Fulton Street, the dessert paradise is easy to miss.    As the son of entrepreneurial parents, co-owner Tan Troung left corporate America and opened Candbaar, the "first San Francisco dessert lounge."  At thirty three, Troung graduated from San Francisco State University and was in the marketing field.  Together with co-owners Derek Chan and Chris Frey, their concept was to create a meeting spot that resembles a living room for desserts and drinks.    The ambiance is a stage short of high-end.  The urban paintings on the wall, dark mahogany tables scattered around the room, and candlelight display create a romantic and cozy setting  Weather you're busy  playing board games with friends or reading the latest coffee table- top book, the ambiance is friendly with a splatter of sexiness.  The best seat is window side where patrons can dabble in chocolate mouse while perking on passer bys.  With soft indie rocks in the background, the space is fit for a great after dinner spot.    While the pros of being his own boss includes doing something that he has full passion towards, the young entrepreneur admits that cons include not having a steady paycheck, no health insurance, and no scheduled vacations.   His best advice for hiring reliable employees is to find people that you enjoy being around and not just looking for experience.     A mound of shoe-string fennel, the smoked sturgeon salad refreshed the palate.  Miniature beeries add sweet tones and compliments the fluffy lemon crème fraiche.  Arriving in a nutty burnt cheese crust, the sweet onion apple soup was the comfort dish of the night.  Infused with apple cider, the full bodied soup balanced richness with a dash of tartness.    Artfully presented in a straight line, beef boulettes swimming in thick juiced carrot finished the savory course.  Made from angus beef, boulettes lacked tenderness but instead the robut beef taste played center stage. A glass of Stonehaven Sparkling Rose from Australia ($8.5) paired well with our dishes.  Trekking to the main attraction, the chocolate mousse ($8) alerted the senses with a creamy rich texture.  As a temperature contrast, a peanut butter ice cream added nutty notes.  The buttermilk panna cotta ($8) exemplifies the new play on dessert: sweet n salty.  With frozen grapes sprinkles on the side, a few dashes of grey salt balanced the custard dessert.  My favorite dessert is the apple pie ice cream ($8).  Served with a triangle pie crust, the deconstructed apple pie ice cream contains all the flavors found in the all American dessert.  Service is attentive including frequent plate changes and water being refilled.  With a mouthful of mousse and dancing around moves on a board game, the lounge is worth a visit.  * I also include some pix * Note: I met Tan at the Elite Fashion Show Event. He was serving up some killer dessert that night. rock on!

H3TdpGEM_s6de0ePeFAVpQ.review_text: I came in with high hopes and expected to be amazed. I walked in and was sorely disappointed that the place was..just kind of a cheap hang out.. did not really rival my favorite dessert places of SF or LA.. it's kind of just a teens and young adults lounge, with old boardgames, loud music, cheap alcohol and kind of not fantastic artwork. I just turned 20, why isn't any of this cool?   We waited an unfathomably long amount of time to get seated. While I waited I watched the bartender pouring heavy syrup into champagne glasses, which I assumed was supposed to be cocktails, but it came off as kind of cheap and icky. Needless to say, sitting near the bar turned me off to all the cocktails.  By the time we got seated I still wanted to give the place an unbiased chance. Just because the beginning was rough doesn't mean the desserts were bad. The waiter comes around taking our drink order, I find the one drink I actually want .. something they cant ruin with syrup or carbonation.. Port! Of course they were out of that though. Whatever, dessert can still happen without that. We skip drinks, order our desserts. Panna cotta with balsamic and strawberries and tiramisu..My absolute favorites. They deliver promptly (cool!). I take my first bite of Panna cotta and almost choke on the balsamic vinegar. I had to fight the urge to not instantaneously spit it out.  I try another bite, my eyes watered, something was soo off.. We tried mixing up the layers of panna cotta to this mush to try and make it more edible, but it was still disgusting.  The tiramisu? Nearly inedible. Seriously bad. The rum (?) flavor burned my nose it was so overwhelming.  I wasn't sure if they were just having an off night, or if the staff had something personal against us..but I decided it was more then likely option C.. They were trying to kill me. the dessert made my bf and I quite nauseous and later I got some sort of stomach bug..  How did candybar fuck up dessert so bad? Q_Q

PFlJjve41Ez4AVYLPpu9qQ.review_text: Candy and its a bar. The desserts were great and the apple pie crumble was delicious. get the apple crumble!

eQJtcM6rK0-x2F2UlZaNJg.review_text: Happy Hour! 6-8 $2 Pacifico, $3 Sangria, $4 bubbly and $5 bubbly cocktails.  What a great place to take a date.    The desserts are not cheap, but damn they're good.

guZ0BJy5mbqhLaAhacOjig.review_text: Deserts are unique and delicious! Service is good.  Great place for a date.

O1JFjkzIDeAMVAhehDb-MQ.review_text: I really liked the concept of a dessert & wine lounge concept and wish there were more places like this in my neck of the woods (San Diego).  My hubby and I came here for happy hour and ordered the red velvet cake and... 3 drinks for myself.  I tend to indulge when I am out of my area.. And I got a little tipsy.  But hey, if the drinks are cheap and i probably won't be back for a while.. I might as well..  As far as the red velvet, it must come pre-made because the hubby didn't like coconut and asked for it without it, but that couldn't be done.  It was a small piece for $9 and kind of dry.  The coconut was good though.  As far as the drinks, totally worth happy hour prices.  I had the blood orange bellini which I read was to be good, but I thought this was just ok.  The strawberry kiss didn't have much of a strawberry flavor and tasted like plain champagne but it looked really pretty.  And the red sangria was just ok as well.  But what i dig about this place is that you can relax, play connect four, read books which are provided, and just hang out in a good atmosphere.  And because happy hour prices rock.

u9KhzES5reUljwccEyFdJw.review_text: I'm always sold when dessert is involved!! Fun to do something different while eating dessert! Enjoyed playing a couple trivia games while we waited for a table. I'd definitely go back!

_00iVeiKJl6Bu-ezOBFWsQ.review_text: I'd love to know how the desserts are, but didn't get the chance.  Took 10 minutes for our waiter to come over.  When he did, I asked a question about a sauce on one of those dishes.  He acted annoyed and gave a not at all helpful answer, finishing with "so do you know what you want?"  My girlfriend and I hadn't decided quite yet.  I asked if we could get a couple waters while we agreed on something.  The dude just rolled his eyes and walked away!!  10 minutes later, after the jackass still hasn't returned, but did serve glasses of water to the two tables on each side of us, we had long since had enough and walked out.  I don't care how good your little desserts and cocktails are, it's ridiculous to have such poor customer service.

rHOt9tVhkCepLOY8_4xsxw.review_text: I was visiting friends in San Francisco one rainy night and we had decided to play board games after dinner. There was one issue we all had a craving for something sweet and a few cocktails. My friends had brought up a place that served only desserts and cocktails, plus they provided board games for entertainment. It was a no brainer, we were walking through the door of Candybar a few minutes later.  I was pleased with the initial impressions of the restaurant. A nice crowd had gathered to escape the rain and socialize. The restaurant was divided up into a bar, lounge, and restaurant style sitting. We claimed a section of the lounge to ourselves and began looking over the menu. One of my friends had visited Candybar a few weeks ago and said there were a few changes to the menu. Right away I realized that this place gets creative and changes their menu often with the ingredients they have at hand.   As we waited for our dishes we placed an order for cocktails. I was not pleased with the concoction of red wine and coke, neither was the person next to me who ordered to the same thing. It seemed that everyone else at the table enjoyed their cocktails of sparkling wine mixed with mango sorbet.    We ordered several dishes and I had mixed feelings when they started to come out. The presentations of the dishes were appealing and everything looked tasty. I dug into the Apple a la Mode right away and discovered it was over powered by cinnamon. We ordered the Candybar Hot Chocolate and if it wasn't for the homemade marshmallow the dish would have been a bust. It wasn't until the Peanut Butter Jelly Time landed in front of me that I found myself in diabetic heaven. A great chocolate tart and peanut butter cream to lay the foundation topped with an amazing grape jelly and blackberries. Great dish and I would highly recommend it. I believe they also offer gluten free options.  It was a little difficult to signal the attention of the staff to clear our plates and empty glasses. We had finished and begun to set-up our game of RISK. It wasn't until I began to stack the glasses that someone rushed over to clear the table. It also seemed difficult to keep the water glasses full. This may have been that it was close to closing time and the staff was in their recovery phase from a long night of service.  Overall I enjoyed the restaurant. Mainly for the ambiance and the peanut butter and jelly dessert. The board games for guest is a cool concept and it could be a great date spot after dinner. I would suggest NOPA since it's down the street, or you can do dessert at Candy Bar and then a late night dinner at NOPA. You can see your dates competitive side in a fun casual environment and flirt at the same time.

zQvBRYbPrRA4WWcIDMocUg.review_text: Games and sweets, sounds good to me!  The best is their happy hour which is until 8pm with $3 house champagne, or their.. SANGRIA! Their White and Red sangria is super delicious and sweet enough for you got for a few glasses.  Such a cute spot. It's great for a date - whether an actual date or in my case, a date with my girlfriends - you can't really go wrong with good dessert, good ambience, good vibes.  The portions are a little small but nicely presented.  Their Ginger Ice cream that comes with their apple pie, doe......... I'm loving it.  The service is awesome. They were super patient and funny cause they totally joked around with us. It was overall a super cute spot!

kf7LReNOwTBndcQlwxO6sg.review_text: 3 1/2 stars, really, but a round down for the residual awkwardness. the wines are all unusual/ones you've mostly never heard of, which is good for the sake of variety but bad for sake of trying to figure out what sounds like something you want to invest $10-15 in.  the best thing we had was a sweet sparkling red, and we only ordered that b/c we kept seeing it sent out and were curious.   food-wise, we just had a cheese plate, and it was good, but what cheese plate isn't? the set up is wacky, with couches that face each other across an otherwise empty front area, forcing you to stare at strangers instead of those you're with.  the staff/ownership is very nice, but they were too obviously nervous, frequently asking if the sound, lighting, etc., was palatable.  you could sense the unease, which was strange, and i felt like i should be reassuring them that everything would be ok, it would all work out.  and that's just so weird, ya know?  especially at a place that should be romantic, that has all the key elements of romance- save for the spirit, the most important part.   candybar has tons of potential, if only they can turn the sterility into a natural-feeling cosy spot.

oEvsA_IvL0yRyI7d4lT-IA.review_text: I liked the idea of a dessert bar but didn't find the desserts or drinks to be interesting or noteworthy. We shared the strawberry kiss, the lychee bellini (the winner), the ice cream sandwich, and the tiramisu. The honeydew melon sorbet was delicious but everything else I could do without. I think many fine dining restaurants have desserts that are better than the ones found here, IMHO.

E3DhTZ720FSb2REOec0Wyg.review_text: Desserts are average.  Drinks are horrible -- way too sweet and barely any alcohol. . . ambience is weird.  If you're a normal person with a well-developed palate, go somewhere else.  Or stay at home.

7AJf_V6MiSmLN-4zN_h75Q.review_text: I absolutely love this place! My boyfriend and I came here with our friends for a double date and we had so much fun. The desserts here are amazing, I highly recommend the drunken s'mores and the ice cream sandwich. There are a lot of gluten free options here which is great! There is a nice drink selection here as well. The inside of the lounge is dimly lit (which is why most people's pictures of their orders aren't of great quality) but it has a nice feel to it. There are numerous interesting paintings on the wall which I love because I appreciate unique decor. My boyfriend, our friends and I picked a board game from the nice selection available there to play while we ate our dessert and drank. It was such a chill and nice way to spend time with friends. The dessert was delicious and the drinks were good too. The quality of the dishes and our experience here was just superb. I'm glad we decided to come here for some late night fun.

gEx19xm2RZQo4XdobKGkWQ.review_text: hmmm...  i love the concept of a dessert lounge and feel there should be more places like this but even though the staff was friend and the setting was great but the menu was just, well, pretentious.  when i see something like "foie PB&J" then i'm thinking that they are catering to a much different crowd.  especially the way they present themselves.  oh well.    we headed over after the green tea ice cream dessert at tsunami didn't sound appetizing.  we got the chocolate parfait and the chocolate cannelone and while tasty, i wouldn't classify them as instant hits.  i hope this place evolves more as time goes on and they start making the dishes more approachable (how the hell feta ice cream is approachable is beyond me).  right now i just think the menu is a bit outlandish and is a push at trying to be upscale for the sake of it.

Y8adrWFzckrjuC11aAs9Og.review_text: This review is a LONG time coming. My very hip auntie and uncle took me here on my 22nd birthday and it left a lasting impression. This is a great place to unwind after dinner or a great place to kick off your night. They have really good happy hour deals and the prices on both the desserts and drinks are reasonable. I couldn't tell you what exactly to get, but I would suggest trying a bit of everything each time you go. They have plenty of artwork around the walls to hold your attention and a lot of board games available. My suggestion, head over to Little Star Pizza for dinner, Candy Bar for dessert/drinks and then enjoy a concert over at The Independent. For those of you looking for something to do on Valentine's day, this may be a great place to make a first impression on a date and break the ice a bit.

cNqpVwQu8bB6sqTua8Wd5w.review_text: What a sweet Friday night at Candybar ;) Along with the delicious happy hour cocktails (I recommend the mango bellini and passion fruit drink) and a plethora of board/card games including my favorite, UNO, we enjoyed the best desserts:   Honey lavendar semifreddo- Like biting into a bouquet of aromatic flowers. Drizzled with rich nutella powder and bites of cantaloupe. Delicious!   Trio of chocolate cupcakes - Green tea, raspberry and dark chocolate infused. Cupcake Wars judges would enjoy this moist menage troi.   Blueberry ice cream sandwich - The macaroons, I could die for.   Strawberry panna cotta - Mhmmm quite the seductively scrumptious lightly sweet dessert. Feed your man with a spoon full of this.

lK_32lYJ-p_fjc01G-DPLw.review_text: Yummy drinks, interesting art, and best of all: BOARD GAMES!

Xj4NPAq2efs4mzS4kFHGyQ.review_text: Candybar is quite the eclectic spot, with its pop art, trendy soundtrack, amorous patrons, and elegant desserts. Something between a lounge and a romantic late-night spot, the menu tempts with a deconstructed apple tart, Japanese cheesecake, lavender semifreddo, and flourless chocolate cake with a gorgeous, silky, rich white chocolate bark infused with orange. Allowing us to pair the gingerbread soft ice cream with the chocolate was generous, but I recommend going with the mango yogurt ice cream for truly refreshing flavors. A small, considered selection of wines, ports, and sherries reflects the elegant dessert profiles and smooth vibe of the place, while the boardgames are cute but confusing.

a8Ttgr3TJUjApRMpCzppWA.review_text: i just love this place - the happy hour is awesome and they got these beautiful new champagne flutes and added a jasmine cocktail to the entourage of happy hour cocktails.  I still like the blood organge the best though.

4eR6hYFJcBHoAqhuOS07ww.review_text: Great concept but could use a little better execution. This is a good place to come hang out with friends, kid-friendly (tons of games), or just enjoy dessert. While the menu looks really promising, the desserts are a little underwhelming for how much I hyped them up in my head. Still, good dessert though.   Lavender honey creme fraiche - one of the lighter desserts. Individually, it tasted good but as a whole dish, it was a little weird.  Drunken s'mores - really heavy dessert. It was okay but left me feeling really thirsty.  The service is pretty slow so hopefully you're not in a big rush or you will be annoyed. Parking is really terrible but that shouldn't surprise you either.

pMAwK2vBedwXrYNScwsl1g.review_text: This place is A-OK.  not great enough to keep me coming back.  i might consider it if i'm in the neighborhood.  the service was okay. the deserts were good, but not great. the presentation of the deserts were great.  cool place to hang out and chill, they have some board games to play.  but i must say.  they have the BEST mint ice cream I've ever tasted in my life.  it made me realize how fake all the other mint ice creams i've ever had tasted.

VOE05znnikDll8rZ2Rjoiw.review_text: Dessert: pretty good. Not exceptionally tasty, but decent.  Atmosphere: Really chill, ambient, relaxing, nice. Good for dates/small groups, probably not ideal for large groups. The place is a bit small, sort of cramped.   Overall: A bit too expensive for very small plates of dessert.

pNDsq4v56zTT2xhyYvUMQQ.review_text: I came here with a friend from out of town expecting it to be like Finale's in Boston or Spot or Chikalicious Dessert Bar in NY.  It looks a bit like a contradiction, as people are fairly well dressed (I think I saw a couple suits even) in a place where the furniture style is that of a well-to-do college dorm with most people sitting on couches in the front, with more formal seating in the back.  The theme of this place is apparently board games, as most tables had either Connect-4, Battleship, or various other games spread on the table alongside their desserts.  We opted to be cheap and try the 4-desserts-for-$25, which limits you to about half the full dessert menu.  The Peanut Butter Jelly Time was probably my favorite, as the taste was literally everything I would want in a PBJ (including some salted candied peanuts for crunch).  The Apple a la Mode, on the other hand, was nothing like eating apple pie, as it was layered to be somewhat stiff in texture and the cream cheese filling threw my taste buds off the trail of familiar comfort.  What was familiar and comforting was the honey almond panna cotta tasted almost like Chinese almond tofu, but not exactly what I was looking for when coming to a higher brow place like this.  The lavender semi freddo was fairly good and what we went to back to most often.  We didn't try any of the cocktails, so maybe we missed out.  The presentation of the desserts was fanciful but we both agreed that the flavors lacked punch, as if the potentially bold flavors were muted and left us wanting more.

ktVRkDDA5eh8IiAsdrhNEQ.review_text: 5 stars - delicious desserts and tasty drinks! A cozy little spot to go to as a couple or with a group.  I used a LivingSocial deal to try this place and will definitely go back again.

PTD6ocdGBUa-dcXS3Vr7Xg.review_text: We stopped by here after a romp around the bay being the jolly little boys we are. The staff is very friendly, and the drinks were questionably good. Only thing is: be prepared to leave your testicles at the door. This place will knock the manliness out of you faster than Yoshi shits eggs.

cRpDa5S1KWICPQaU4pzbWw.review_text: What is it about this place that I will not consider returning?   I did not need to make a reservation (on a Friday night) because there were less than a dozen warm bodies in the place on a chilly night. How is it that about half a block away at Firefly, the bar is full and yet this cozy and warm lighting dessert and wine joint is empty?  I love desserts. My friend loves wine. We both like to play Candyland and Monopoly and there were those games there...hmmm....  Here it is, where are the selections? I mean, there are about five desserts on the menu, 3, I will not eat. So after one visit, are there anything else to look forward to?   I had the chocolate cake with thyme ice cream, which is good but not memorable, or at least not enough for me to write a review about.

j5ezF5mEGpnDwdTmAHci7Q.review_text: The dessert wasn't that great.... drinks were fun but nothing special.   I just had to come because it was "interesting".   HATED the parking.   To be honest, you're not missing much here.    I'd rather go to tea station for boba.

zORQY85qUfWiIEltLOxG1g.review_text: If I was a dude and I've been dating this chick for awhile already and I still haven't gotten any, I'd probably resort to the "Candybar experience".    Yeah I said it, Candybar is the pantie-dropping bar.  Candybar is the perfect spot to take your date after dinner.  The place is very laid back and cozy. It's nice and chill but not library awkwardly quiet.  The room is filled with interesting artwork so if you guys run out of anything interesting to talk about, you can just talk about the art.  You can also play board games.  I recommend sharing the 4 dessert sampler.  From what I tried so far (not from one sitting, I'm not that huge of a heifer):  -Ice cream sandwich: the ice cream is a little too watery but I love how that use macaroons for the sandwich.    -PB Jelly Time: the best one in the menu.  Highly recommended  -Apple a la mode: I'm not really an apple pie kind of girl but the gingerbread ice cream was yummy.  -Japanese Cheesecake: my least favorite so far.  Maybe because I'm not a fan of sorbet.  -Honey Almond Panna Cotto:  The simplest out of the desserts, yet nicely executed.  -Lavender Honey Fraicha: the nutella almost killed the taste of the Lavender.  A little less nutella and a little more lavender, please.  Champagne cocktail + Dessert Sampler + intimate place = sexy time

i-7Mvu1D6LNDkKQWIfqOEw.review_text: Candybar = chill, relaxing, fun.  Go with friends. Go with a hot date. It's a classy place w/o the pretentious on the side.  They have fun art on their walls without being artsy fartsy.  There is a great selection of board games you can pick out to play with your friends or to use as an ice breaker with an awkward date.   Don't be a cheap ass and share one dessert with a group of 4 people. I personally can't do that because the desserts are too delicious to share. Get your own dessert and drink, bitch I ain't sharing.  I'm a fatass and I've tried all their desserts. I honestly enjoy all of them. My favorite is the strawberry limeade, panna cotta, cheescake, carrot cake... um ok the whole menu. However, the pbj time is a bit rich for me only because I'm not a huge pb fan.  There is a good amount of people on Yelp who think they're expert food critics while they don't know sh-t, Just saying. RANT TIME!  For e.g. I've heard/read countless reviews on the Japanese cheesecake. Stating the cake is "spongey" or "not like a normal cheesecake". No duh. It's a JAPANESE cheesecake.   It's made significantly different than a western style cheesecake. Get your facts together if you're such a serious "yelper". In addition to my rant, the Japanese cheesecake actually isn't as spongey as it normally would be in my opinion, I feel it's quite moist for a japanese style cheesecake. It's like a cross breed of Japanese and western cheesecake, like a sexy mixed Asian/White girl.   Also I've heard/seen people stating that the buttermilk vanilla bean panna cotta is sour and or tastes bad/expired. It's made with a balsamic VINEGAR reduction. It is written in the menu. Read. Read people. Please. Ignorance is not bliss it's just retardation.  Thanks, bye.

M19NwFwAXKRZzt8koF11hQ.review_text: (See pics)  Yelpers love to have UYEs here because of its fun environment and great desserts and fun drinks, as well as their Kung Fu taco truck that is here. While this is not totally a mass transit neighborhood it certainly is worth to come out to enjoy some friendly conversations while having some delicious sweetness.

P1pbJ7QSnI9EnyYzy2EnCg.review_text: I wanted to like it. I really, really did.  I even went there twice - something I rarely do when I'm initially underwhelmed - just to make sure they weren't having an off day.  The first time I went with a Groupon and came away mildly disappointed; the second time I paid full price and felt majorly ripped off. Look, the idea is lovely and there is a dearth of places like this in SF but that doesn't help when the execution is just so.....budget. Although the prices aren't: $48 (pre-tip) for 2 drinks and a shared dessert plate?!?  Go with low expectations and a Groupon, or don't go at all. Sorry Candybar.... :-(

0fBeZ7_mcjFcoJgz_of25g.review_text: 1. Fresh and unique lounge bar in SF 2. Ambiance is perfect for friends/ dates - seating is comfortable - romantic - not crowded and not loud  3. Art is very tasteful and stimulating / Games available to keep you entertained at all times. 4. Menu arouses desire to want to try everything  5. And when the owner shows that he really does care about his customers, that's a +.

82dCHyU-ANOgdhxUgZsUeg.review_text: Hmmm, I came here on a random Sunday since my friends wanted to check it out. Other than parking being hard to find, it was a cool experience. I liked the art on the walls and the random board games. The desserts were interesting, but the drinks seemed sort of pricey.  This is a cozy joint I'd recommend for a first date. I wouldn't come here for beer since their selection is lackluster. Get a cocktail, a dessert, and appreciate the art and ambience.

AW-qmn5vcUIQ1Y6NK_-4Tg.review_text: came on a friday night, dim lighting and chill, but fun atmosphere. tons of games to choose from. awesome art on the walls.   the straus yogurt cake is SO delish! so many flavors on one plate, a definite must try! tiramisu was made well, but is just tiramisu. i suggest doing the sampler platter where you can choose 4 different desserts (they come in smaller sizes) for $25. the regular sized desserts were a little too much for me to have all at once. talking to people around me, other favorites seem to be the strawberry limeade and lemon tart. will have to try next time!  drinks weren't bad either. i had the strawberry kiss (champagne, ginger ale, and a frozen strawberry), good but nothing crazy amazing.   all in all, a great hangout spot with friends to make a chill night. i'd go back! :)

p1wEUW7EBrj6Awprk0-TuA.review_text: A cute and unique spot ideal for a night out with friends or after-dinner treat. The rich, coconut-coated red velvet cake comes with the BEST (homemade, too) mint ice cream I've ever had, which tastes no different from the fresh mint leaves I used to pick in my family garden.  All kinds of dessert options; All of them are good.  Oh, and they have board games. :)  Only Downsides: -This place is SMALL. It gets crowded and waits can be long. Call ahead for reservations, if possible. -Board game assortment is random and sometimes you have to wait for your game of choice -A bit pricey for a dessert and drinks spot

ZIziZi16C5j5i2JSpaosGw.review_text: Desserts are light and good. Prices are a bit expensive for the portions. Great drinks!  Tiramisu and the chocolate peanut butter are great.

NsFfswfKLCRb05F0rV3kvw.review_text: Came here for opening night in late March. The place was so jam-packed that me and my friend drank some wine and left to go somewhere else. People were territorial and pushy. Yuck.  Since then, whenever I walk by after work, the place is half packed. I finally went back five months later on a Tuesday night to try the dessert menu.  The server had a great smile, was attractive and very friendly...which might have made my experience all the better (read: HOT...but probably gay knowing my luck).   I had a dessert dish with ice cream and figs and mi amiga had some sort of chocolate creation. We both enjoyed our desserts but agreed that we wouldn't come here on a regular basis. More for special occasions (due to bill total).  Both of us were not "blown away."  I'll just come back for the eye candy...

czIHMzmascJmct_qT7O04g.review_text: Pros: 1) 6-8pm happy hour daily. 2) Chill spot, cool ambiance. 3) Board games. 4) Goat cheese. Ohhh, the cheeses. So little, though. 5) Fat Tire AND Newcastle.   Cons:  1) No "warm", comforting desserts. 2) Could have completely done w/o the chocolate mousse/thyme ice cream combo.  It could have worked if the chocolate was more pungent. 3) Their selection of "cocktails" are blah.  Syrup only makes sparkling wine slightly sweet, not unique or even tasty. 4) Dubya-tee-eff on the portions.  I'm a little girl but this sweet-tooth needs to be fed.  All in all, someone from out of town might be tickled by Candybar.  I'd consider taking my guest here.  It's not quite pretentious yet, but a true sweets and alchy lover will be peeved.  Nothing was unappetizing by any means, more like a little ... uninspired. Yeah, that's it.

dz02c5FVxDRsFdP95IMjPQ.review_text: Hands down, the best carrot cake I've ever had! (sorry grandma) It was served with a scoop of banana ice cream that was amazing and nicely paired with the carrot cake. I also tried the Strawberry Kiss cocktail (champagne and strawberries...in the flute!) and the Lemon-drop shot (soju with a lemon sherbet float in the shot glass). All were yummy and reasonably priced for the quality. I think $7-8 for the Strawberry Kiss, $5 for the shot, and $9 for the cake.    Beautifully served desserts, heavenly flavors, and comfy lounge-like seating. Plus board games! I am sold!  Service was alright. Not mean but not friendly. The desserts were out pretty quick. We didn't have a reservation, and our group of 10 or so lucked out for a table. We got in just before a flood of people around 9:30 on a Friday night, so make a reservation to be safe.

QocP49nZ7Fo-4Rp_QxPuDQ.review_text: if i ever have a nervous breakdown i am coming here to sit next to my favorite (of yet) wall art, order every single desserts, and drink white sangria : )  this place looks excellent for a rainy evening, there are tons of board games to play while sitting in big cushy and dark booths

ZBbONms0uMqWS-lDqPYmsw.review_text: SUCH a cute place! Candybar is perfect to get together with friends to snack, drink, talk, and play games. The setting is adorable and very romantic, in a cute way relaxed way. The dessert menu looks delicious but caution because you can get sweet overload if you order too much. The drinks looked very good too! Look out for Candybar's Groupon deals, which is totally worth it to get! They were super nice about accomerdating our Groupons. Service is wonderful. Street parking (typical SF) so be prepared to walk. They need to create a place like this in Orange County.

TMr5z8JDuGPc0I-5WfpBMQ.review_text: I LOVE this place!  The dessert is absolutely delicious, my friend and I tried the panna cotta (GET THIS ONE!!!) and the lavender dessert that everyone on yelp said to get (which I thought was just alright).  I love the desserts because they are plated so nicely, and the portions are relatively decent to share between two people.  The drinks were good.... but both my friend's blood orange wine and my jasmine lime wine tasted really similar... so not too sure about that.  The reason for the 4-star review is definitely the whole package that Candybar offers.  The BOARD GAMES (we played Connect Four and Battleship) were so fun over dessert and drinks, and the overall atmosphere with all the fun customers was great.  The only negative I have to say is the BITCH waitress who was so disinterested and her forced smiles made her look like an ogre, bitch please, I'm sorry your life is miserable but do your job and gimme some better service!!!

-zXfHXmR-JRBlCDv9I0MZQ.review_text: Love, love, love this place! So cute and quaint! A dessert bar??? I never heard of such a place until I came here! Great desserts with a great selection of drinks! Even their wine list is great with Banyuls! Ask for Chris, he makes most of the drinks and is super sweet! Great place for a date or a group of friends! You can also read some interesting books on wine, champagne, and Dali! There are tons of board games, too!

S8znBB7Hie0tnGh-vVyi9w.review_text: Yummy dessert, good cocktails, and super fun board games!

jy_RGAeAvNeCv5BxZsUWFA.review_text: After eating sushi with Daniel L, Maybeline C, and May's friend Wendy we decided we needed desert. After doing my Wasabi trick I decided I needed some ice cream to put out the fire.  Someone suggested Candybar so off we went.  We got there just in time to miss the Kung Fu Taco happy hour or I would have eaten the hell out of some duck tacos.  I'll list the disappointments by magnitude.  The bread pudding was $8 and no one liked it. Daniel really got excited when I read someone praising it on my iphone yelp app; it seems he'd been craving bread pudding for some time.  The red velvet cake was covered in coconut and came with a small scoop of vanilla for $9. The coconut completely overpowered the cake so I have no idea how good it was. It was a pretty small portion as well.  The Ice cream trio was the best of the bad; it's three truly tiny scooplets of ice cream for $5. They weren't bad but considering that there are many really great ice cream options in The City now it seemed fairly pedestrian.  Looking around I mostly saw people drinking and playing board games but not eating the deserts.

KIUeZpqA5DpQZIhcBwQVvQ.review_text: Stumbled upon this cute spot while bar hopping on Divis. I was aching for dessert and this was the perfect place to grab drinks too.  We were seated quickly and the waitress rushed over to give us menus. The atmosphere is really chill and they played great music. I found myself singing along to some 90s hiphop faves which was awesome.  Once we ordered, it took at least 10 minutes to get our initial drinks.. too slow IMO, especially since the place wasn't super busy. The cocktails were good- I tried the raspberry delight and strawberry champagne. We ordered the cupcake trio (chocolate cakes with assorted icings) and devoured it while I kicked ass at Connect 4 (they have tons of boardgames). It was no Kara's cupcake but still really tasty.  Neat concept for a dessert spot. Service was spotty but overall a fun experience.

8MeD1D70MC-0dIK2Lr11WQ.review_text: I love the idea of this place. Desserts? Cocktails? Board games? MY FAVORITE THINGS.  Unfortunately, the execution just isn't done right. The space looks great, but it's too small and they don't really handle large groups easily. And you're not going to go here to play board games with one other person. So... I don't really get it.  Whatever dessert I had gotten that night, probably something chocolate-y, wasn't that memorable. But it wasn't bad! And it looks like they switch up their menu, so it's probably worth going back to for happy hour or something.

lBIfa3INjAj_z2_amlnq3w.review_text: A cute place to get desserts and play board games. The servers were friendly. but the desserts were overly sweet. We tried the lavender, PBJ, and S'mores, and each were one dimensional and not memorable.

e331pQV1I-SSnWw_w0PfMA.review_text: Dude. Nacho Sundae!  Avocado yogurt, mangoes, kiwis, candied jalapeno, horchata ice cream on sweet crackers............. mmmmmmmmmm.  Sad that it's $8 tho... but it's mega delicious.

eoENqkXPjr9whDyonpo3GA.review_text: I love this place. The ambiance, the desserts, the wine.
